payload.text:
I am tasked with building a website single landing page with the following information attached below.
Homepage Service Overview
Header: Protect Your Business with Expert Cybersecurity Advisory Intro: Our consulting services help organizations of all sizes identify risks, implement security best practices, and transform raw data into actionable intelligence. We focus on advisory, strategy, and detection design — without the operational burden of 24/7 monitoring.

 
Services Page
1. Security Policy & Documentation Development
Overview: We help organizations define and implement security policies and procedures aligned with industry standards and compliance requirements.

What We Deliver: - Information Security Policy - Acceptable Use Policy - Incident Response Plan - AI/Data Handling Policies

Benefits: - Audit-ready documentation - Reduced operational risk - Clear governance for staff and contractors

Visual Suggestion: Document icon or checklist graphic

 
2. Vulnerability Management (Scanning & Reporting)
Overview: Identify, prioritize, and understand vulnerabilities in your systems through automated scanning and risk-based reporting.

What We Deliver: - Monthly vulnerability scans - Executive and technical reports - Risk prioritization guidance - Trend analysis for ongoing risk reduction

Benefits: - Focus on critical vulnerabilities - Clear actionable recommendations - Supports compliance requirements

Visual Suggestion: Shield with magnifying glass or bar chart graphic

 
3. Security Awareness Training & Bulletins
Overview: Reduce human-driven risk with recurring employee training and regular security bulletins.

What We Deliver: - Quarterly security training sessions - Monthly security awareness bulletins - Training completion metrics and feedback

Benefits: - Improved security culture - Reduced phishing and social engineering risks - Supports compliance and audit readiness

Visual Suggestion: Calendar or classroom icon graphic

 
4. Phishing Simulation Service
Overview: Reduce the risk of phishing attacks by testing employee awareness through safe, realistic simulated campaigns. This service complements Security Awareness Training by identifying vulnerabilities, reinforcing learning, and measuring improvements in human security behavior.

What We Deliver: - Customized phishing simulation campaigns tailored to your organization - Analytics on employee responses and engagement metrics - Follow-up recommendations for improving security awareness - Executive summary highlighting high-risk areas and trends

Benefits: - Identify employees at higher risk of phishing attacks - Reinforce training with practical, hands-on exercises - Demonstrate measurable improvements in security awareness - Provide leadership with actionable insights for decision-making

Visual Suggestions: - Email icon with shield overlay - Target or dartboard icon representing simulated attacks - Flow diagram: “Simulated Email → Employee Action → Analytics → Training Feedback”


Use the website below as inspiration 
https://www.turingtower.com/turing-intel

**Defining the Project Scope**

Okay, I'm starting by zeroing in on the core request: a landing page for a cybersecurity advisory firm. I'm prioritizing the firm's advisory services in the header. The content requirements are a great starting point for fleshing this out. I need to figure out how to best integrate all the details.


**Analyzing Service Strategies**

I am now focusing on the services the advisory firm offers, as well as the strategy and detection design. I am not considering 24/7 monitoring. I have the basic services drafted, and I am going to move on to refining them for the landing page. Turing Tower's aesthetic is providing me with an excellent design strategy. The dark theme is a strong starting point.


**Designing the UI Elements**

I'm now zeroing in on UI design, particularly color schemes and typography. I'm leaning toward dark gray backgrounds accented by whites, metallic grays, and a cyber-green or electric blue primary color. I also have a sans-serif typeface, clean monolithic headings, and layout structure in mind, including a hero section with a strong headline and abstract background. Service grids are a must.


**Building the React Components**

I'm now in the process of building out the reusable React components. I've got the `ServicesSection.tsx` container ready, along with `PhishingDiagram.tsx` for the specific phishing service visual and `Contact.tsx` for the CTA. I also set up a `types.ts` file for the service data interface. Content drafting, including icons, for each service, is underway.

**Enhancing the Aesthetic**

I've been working on refining the "Turing Tower" aesthetic. I'll be using `framer-motion` for scroll reveal animations and implementing Tailwind's `backdrop-blur`, low opacity borders, and gradients. For the fonts, I will be implementing Inter or a similar system sans-serif font. I am getting ready to dive into the code implementation steps next.


**Implementing the Component Logic**

I am now focused on the component logic and initial implementation. I've started by adding the Tailwind CDN and defining the `Service` interface in `types.ts`. I also populated the content in `constants.ts` and created reusable UI elements, like buttons and cards, to keep the code clean. I'm building out the flow diagram for the phishing service and assembling the components in `App.tsx`, focusing on a big, bold hero section and a service grid. I'm adding expanding detail sections to each service card to reduce text clutter.


**Visualizing the Flow**

I'm now focusing on the phishing service diagram. I plan to use `lucide-react` icons and arrows to represent the workflow. I'll maintain high contrast with a black background and white text, while also utilizing subtle borders. I'm prioritizing clean design and easy readability. I can use the Tailwind CDN and I am not including any unnecessary dependencies. I will rely on standard React and Tailwind for animations, and lightweight state/effect hooks for simple reveals to ensure this implementation is lightweight. I will use `group-hover` for interactions to add subtle dynamism.

entries.description: Root HTML file with Tailwind CSS and Font imports
TypeScript definitions for service data structures
Static content data for the website

diffs.replacement:
import { FileText, ShieldAlert, Users, MailWarning } from 'lucide-react';
import { ServiceItem } from './types';

export const HERO_CONTENT = {
  header: "Protect Your Business with Expert Cybersecurity Advisory",
  intro: "Our consulting services help organizations of all sizes identify risks, implement security best practices, and transform raw data into actionable intelligence. We focus on advisory, strategy, and detection design — without the operational burden of 24/7 monitoring."
};

export const SERVICES: ServiceItem[] = [
  {
    id: "policy",
    title: "Security Policy & Documentation Development",
    overview: "We help organizations define and implement security policies and procedures aligned with industry standards and compliance requirements.",
    deliverables: [
      "Information Security Policy",
      "Acceptable Use Policy",
      "Incident Response Plan",
      "AI/Data Handling Policies"
    ],
    benefits: [
      "Audit-ready documentation",
      "Reduced operational risk",
      "Clear governance for staff"
    ],
    icon: FileText,
    visualType: 'list'
  },
  {
    id: "vulnerability",
    title: "Vulnerability Management",
    overview: "Identify, prioritize, and understand vulnerabilities in your systems through automated scanning and risk-based reporting.",
    deliverables: [
      "Monthly vulnerability scans",
      "Executive & technical reports",
      "Risk prioritization guidance",
      "Trend analysis"
    ],
    benefits: [
      "Focus on critical vulnerabilities",
      "Clear actionable recommendations",
      "Supports compliance requirements"
    ],
    icon: ShieldAlert,
    visualType: 'chart'
  },
  {
    id: "training",
    title: "Security Awareness Training",
    overview: "Reduce human-driven risk with recurring employee training and regular security bulletins.",
    deliverables: [
      "Quarterly training sessions",
      "Monthly awareness bulletins",
      "Training metrics & feedback"
    ],
    benefits: [
      "Improved security culture",
      "Reduced social engineering risks",
      "Audit readiness"
    ],
    icon: Users,
    visualType: 'calendar'
  },
  {
    id: "phishing",
    title: "Phishing Simulation Service",
    overview: "Reduce the risk of phishing attacks by testing employee awareness through safe, realistic simulated campaigns. Complements training by reinforcing learning.",
    deliverables: [
      "Customized simulation campaigns",
      "Employee response analytics",
      "Follow-up recommendations",
      "Executive summary of trends"
    ],
    benefits: [
      "Identify high-risk employees",
      "Reinforce training practically",
      "Measurable improvements"
    ],
    icon: MailWarning,
    visualType: 'flow'
  }
];

entries.description: Visual flow diagram for phishing service

payload.text:
**Investigating the Import Issue**

I'm currently focused on resolving a "Cannot find name 'MailWarning'" error within `components/ServiceCard.tsx`, specifically on line 141. My investigation centers on the imports within that file. Right now, I'm examining them for the source of the `MailWarning` definition.


**Pinpointing the Import Location**

I've located the missing import: `MailWarning` is indeed sourced from 'lucide-react' in the `constants.tsx` file, but it's not present where it's needed in `components/ServiceCard.tsx`. My next step is to add it to the import statement within `ServiceCard.tsx` to fix the "Cannot find name" error. I'm double-checking now for syntax errors before deploying the fix.


**Confirming the Fix**

I've verified the fix. I updated the import statement in `ServiceCard.tsx` to include `MailWarning` from 'lucide-react', and the 'Cannot find name' error is resolved. I've double-checked that `PhishingFlow.tsx` and `constants.tsx` don't require updates. The import statement has been updated. I'll test deployment.


**Verifying the Code**

I'm confirming that line 141 in `ServiceCard.tsx` contains the `MailWarning` component, as expected. The code block confirms the usage. I've also verified that the error stems from a missing import. I'm double checking that the `ServiceItem` type in `types.ts` uses the `MailWarning` icon in `constants.tsx`, confirming the requirement. The fix is now clear. I just need to add the import and test.


**Addressing the Visual Type Discrepancy**

I've determined the discrepancy lies in how the icon is rendered based on `service.visualType`. My earlier fixes for the import didn't go far enough. Specifically, the component uses `MailWarning` directly. I need to make sure the import is correct within that specific block. I've re-examined `ServiceCard.tsx` and confirmed the direct usage within the visual type `flow` block. This confirms the specific import requirement. I'll focus on resolving this and will verify the related code block. I believe I have the fix.


**Analyzing the Redundancy**

I've confirmed the import of `MailWarning` in `ServiceCard.tsx`, addressing the initial error. Now, I'm analyzing the component logic. I observe that when `service.visualType` is 'flow', both `PhishingFlow` and a `MailWarning` icon are rendered, which appears redundant. I need to figure out which visual indicator to use.


**Refining the Logic**

I've been re-examining `ServiceCard.tsx`, specifically focusing on how `PhishingFlow` is rendered in relation to the main visual container. It appears `PhishingFlow` is rendered *after* the container. The closing `div` on line 148 is closing the container. This clarifies the layout and interaction of the components. I'm now thinking about whether this is the intended visual layout.


**Clarifying the Component Usage**

I've re-examined the code block from `ServiceCard.tsx` and the use of the `MailWarning` icon within the conditional rendering based on `service.visualType === 'flow'`. This means the `MailWarning` icon is used to indicate the flow visual type is active, while `PhishingFlow` provides the flow's specific content. I'll test deployment after.


**Optimizing the Import**

I've added `MailWarning` to the import statement in `ServiceCard.tsx` from `lucide-react` as initially required. After fixing the reported error, I'm now examining the unused imports. Specifically, I see `BarChart` from `lucide-react` is imported, but not used in this file. I'll test deployment. I'll focus on fixing the error, then I'll evaluate any cleanup.


**Evaluating the UI Layout**

I'm now carefully examining the layout and user interface of `ServiceCard.tsx`, specifically how the `MailWarning` icon and `PhishingFlow` components are presented together. I'm focusing on user experience, and evaluating whether combining the indicator and flow visualization is the best approach. My thoughts center around whether the presentation is clear and intuitive for the end-user. I'll test.


**Refining the Component Logic**

I'm now diving deeper into how `ServiceCard` renders based on `service.visualType`. I need to ensure the correct components display in each scenario, considering the interplay between visual indicators and content. It's really about ensuring that the components are rendering in a streamlined way. I'm focusing on the condition where 'flow' is active. I'll check my changes, then verify functionality.


**Evaluating the Component Structure**

I'm now digging into the component rendering, specifically focusing on the conditional block determining the visual presentation. It's about streamlining how different visual elements interact within the `ServiceCard`. I am considering how the 'flow' visual type interacts with the other types, to ensure efficient rendering. I'll check my approach, then I'll test.


**Implementing the Chart Display**

I'm now focusing on displaying the chart for `service.visualType === 'chart'`. I'm examining the provided code block, specifically the `<PieChart>` and `<Pie>` components. I need to integrate the provided data and ensure the chart renders correctly within the existing layout and component structure. I will verify that the layout displays well.


**Integrating the Chart Data**

I'm now integrating the chart data, `chartData`, into the `<PieChart>` component in `ServiceCard.tsx`, specifically when `service.visualType === 'chart'`. I'm focusing on populating the chart with `value`, `color`, and other information. I've been verifying that the data maps correctly to the `<Pie>` and `<Cell>` components. Next, I'll test the chart display to confirm visual representation.


**Refining the Chart Integration**

I've been examining the code again, this time honing in on how to render the chart in the `ServiceCard` when `service.visualType === 'chart'`. I need to ensure a fluid integration and seamless user experience, and have been examining that the provided chart data will display appropriately and effectively. Next, I'll test the chart's display, and adjust as needed.

entries.description: Import MailWarning from lucide-react to fix reference error

payload.text: Why is the code base empty when I load it on localhost but not on here

**Diagnosing the Discrepancy**

I'm now focusing on a strange discrepancy. The React application, based on Vite/ESM, displays correctly here but appears empty on localhost. The `importmap` in the `index.html` suggests a modern JavaScript module setup, which should be consistent across environments. I'm suspecting some kind of pathing or configuration issue related to the local server, likely related to how modules are being resolved.


**Pinpointing the Omission**

I've got it! I was meticulously examining the ESM setup, and the `importmap` seemed correct. Then, reviewing the `index.html` again, it's glaringly obvious. The file *does not* include a script tag importing `index.tsx` . That's why the app is empty locally. I must add the script tag to include `index.tsx`.


**Adding the Entry Point**

I've determined the final piece of the puzzle. I missed a crucial HTML tag: the script tag that loads the entry point. The HTML has the `importmap` for ESM imports in place, but lacks the necessary `<script type="module" src="/index.tsx"></script>`. This omission is why the React application doesn't render locally. Adding this tag will fix it!


**Confirming the Missing Import**

I've circled back to the root cause. While ESM and Vite are set up, my assumption about automatic import was incorrect based on the provided `index.html` structure. The HTML is missing the necessary `<script>` tag. Specifically, I'm going to add `<script type="module" src="./index.tsx"></script>`. This omission is what prevents the app from rendering. I'm also confirming the CDN `importmap` is fine.


**Analyzing the Execution**

I'm now considering the execution environment. I'm verifying the MIME types and correct serving of files on localhost, assuming internet access is present. However, the primary cause is often the missing entry point connection between HTML and JS. Since JSX isn't natively executable, and they're on localhost, I'm checking if they use a bundler like Vite. The `<script type="module" src="/index.tsx"></script>` tag is the right approach if using Vite, which is suggested if they use "npm run dev". I am going to update `index.html` to include the script tag.


**Implementing the Entrypoint**

I'm now implementing the solution. Adding the script tag `<script type="module" src="/index.tsx"></script>` to `index.html` should resolve the issue. This inclusion is the missing link, ensuring that the React application, despite being correctly structured with ESM, is actually loaded by the browser on localhost. I have made the edit and confirmed it in the code.


**Refining the Styles**

I'm now refining the style definitions. I've updated the theme with specific colors for the UI elements, including electric blue, emerald green, and a dark background. I've also incorporated a slow pulse animation for the loading component, along with glass panel effects to enhance the visual appeal.


**Verifying the Import**

I've circled back to the importmap configuration after confirming the script tag in HTML. My initial concern was about an implicit resolution of "react-dom/client" through "react-dom/", but it seems standard ESM. The provided importmap and the esm.sh CDN handle subpath imports correctly. I'm focusing back on the main issue: the missing script tag. The importmap is working as expected.


**Adding the Dependencies**

I'm now incorporating specific module imports. I've re-examined dependencies, noticing `lucide-react` is correctly configured via the import map. There's no problem there. I'm also ensuring the handling of `react-dom/client` is consistent and explicit, although the current implementation is acceptable. I'm focused on the `<script>` tag. Specifically, I'll add `<script type="module" src="/index.tsx"></script>`. I will be updating the CDN dependencies.


**Evaluating the Assumptions**

I'm now evaluating the implicit assumptions. My thought process is focusing on the potential setup discrepancies. I've re-examined dependency handling; `react-dom/client` is correctly managed. However, the presence of "localhost" suggests a possible non-Vite execution environment, a detail that I missed. I'm focusing on the setup: the `<script>` tag is essential, but local execution without a build step could be the root.


**Confirming the Injection**

I'm now confirming the script tag injection. Even though this seems basic, I'm reinforcing the Vite entry point strategy. I will add the necessary `<script>` tag within `index.html` to load the entry point. The 'here' environment functions, but locally, I must ensure the browser knows where to start. Also, I'll explicitly include `react-dom/client` within the importmap for comprehensive setup.

I am confirming the addition of the script tag, and ensuring that the `importmap` covers essential dependencies. This ensures that the application has the correct entry point defined to handle the module execution. Specifically, I'm focusing on the `<script type="module" src="/index.tsx"></script>` addition to `index.html`, and will make sure the changes are included in the update.


**Validating the Configuration**

I'm now validating the configuration. I'm focusing on the `index.html` structure. It's crucial the script tag loads the entry point correctly. Now that the styles are implemented, I'm checking to make sure the changes I've implemented are visible. I've re-examined dependencies, noticing `lucide-react` is correctly configured via the import map. There's no problem there.

I've also confirmed that the `importmap` is correctly handling all of the dependencies.

The reason the app appears empty on your localhost is that the `index.html` file was missing the script tag to actually load the React application (`index.tsx`).

In many online preview environments, the entry point is sometimes handled automatically or injected by the platform. However, when running locally (e.g., with Vite), you must explicitly tell the HTML file which JavaScript file to execute.

I have updated `index.html` to include the script tag pointing to your entry file and refined the import map to ensure stable dependency loading.

entries.description: Add missing script tag to load the React application entry point and refine importmap
